key_insight: A scene-centric, zero-shot system that reconstructs metric in-scene object manipulations from monocular RGB video by combining foundation-model initializations with joint optimization for physically plausible hand–object–scene interactions. This yields accurate, usable 3D reconstructions without per-scene training.
problem_solved: Reconstructing in-scene object manipulation from a single RGB video — overcoming ill-posed scene reconstruction, ambiguous hand–object depth, and the need for physically plausible interactions that prior hand-centric methods ignored.
method: Initialize core components (object mesh, hand pose, and scene geometry) using data-driven foundation models from raw monocular RGB.
Optimize all elements jointly in a shared scene (metric) coordinate frame with contact, depth, and physics-informed priors to disambiguate hand–object depth and ensure plausible interactions.
Zero-shot inference: operate without scene-specific training, producing metric-accurate reconstructions suitable for downstream use (e.g., AR/robotics).
impact: Enables practical, metric-quality 3D reconstructions of real-world hand-object interactions from ordinary videos — useful for robotics, AR/VR, activity analysis, and dataset generation without costly multi-view or depth sensors.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: foundation-model initialization → joint scene-centric optimization → final metric reconstruction
Before/after comparison: hand-centric reconstruction vs. scene-centric reconstruction overlaid on the input video frame
Contact/physics visualization: heatmap or force arrows showing enforced contact regions and collision corrections
Metric depth/mesh overlay: reconstructed object mesh and hand trajectory in a 3D scene coordinate frame (with scale)
paper_title: Zero-shot Reconstruction of In-Scene Object Manipulation from Video
paper_authors: Dixuan Lin, Tianyou Wang, Zhuoyang Pan, Yufu Wang, Lingjie Liu
